segments.text: Four years since I have taught.
Yes.
And I love it.
Yes.
It's just one of those things.
Well, you know, I love, to me, the second graders were my, was my pet group.
I love them children.
Full of, full of questions.
Full of, I mean, everything is new to them.
They want to hear everything.
And they need you so badly.
You're faster the first year when they're so immature.
and when they asked for their mother so desperately.
We had a very, very crucial situation at Montrose because of lack of space, which is always the case.
Was this school in a poorer district of the Grado?
Yes, yes.
It was in a poorer district.
We had some children of very high
Income.
But scarcely one, two, three, four.
Just, you could count them in your fingers.
But first grades, I remember when I was a principal, first graders were always crying.
Always crying.
And there was a little girl who cried every day, so I told the teacher, you bring it to me.
And I told her, now look, you've never used a telephone?
No.
I said, all right, from now on you're going to answer the phone for me.
And so she would pick up the receipt and say, Monroe School.
She would say, Monroe School.
Little things like that.
And you know, that finally gave her the security that she was just not being thrown in there and forgotten.
And I insisted, I even asked, I said, well, why?
To me, I thought, if first graders, if a school as crowded as we are,
could rent a house nearby and give the children the atmosphere of home rather than of school while they get used to it, I think they would do better.
But of course those were dreams that I had.
I had many dreams.
I don't think of first graders, at least in my children's experience, as being particularly unhappy.
I'm sure there are adjustments.
They were not unhappy, except for my daughter.
My children always attended a private school the first years.
They went to Mrs. Ellis, and she was a wonderful teacher.
So they did first and second grade, or first grade at least.
Then from there on, they would put them in the public schools.
But not my daughter.
She went to Ersinine.
which is run by nuns.
And Mariangela started getting sick, and she was sick.
And every day they would call me at Montrose and say, Mariangela is sick.
So I would ask Mr. Barris, he said, all right.
Of course, I was in the office.
If I go pick her up, yes, go right ahead.
So I'd come and pick her up and bring her home.
Or she would, she even walked to my sister's, which was about five blocks.
And I said, I'm going to get to the bottom of this.
There's something.
There definitely is something, because she would actually get sick.
The nun, the sister who was teaching her the first half year, was fine.
But there was a sister, Ana Maria, who was a great big, and she had a heart of gold.
But she was very big, very tall, dressed in black,
And the girls, the older girls, made her think that Sister Ana Maria was very, very mean.
And if her teacher would walk out of the room, the older girls knew what would scare her.
So they told her, Sister Ana Maria is going to take our class.
And that just petrified her.
I really had to search.
and get to the bottom of it.
And so I decided, I went to the sisters and I told them what my problem was.

And I said, I want you, would you please, would you consider coming over to the house, and it was during more or less around Christmas time, and let Maria Angela show you the Christmas tree and the, we always put the nacimiento.
And I told Maria Angela, we're going to have guests.
You know who's coming?
Sister Cornelius, I believe that was her name.
Sister, I can't remember the other one.
And Sister Ana Maria.
And I said, yes, she's coming to see us.
And so they came.
And they sat in our living room over there.
And Sister Ana Maria held her little hand, which I'm sure was like a piece of ice.
She was frozen.
She realized that Sister Ana Maria was just a big woman.
But she wasn't going to hurt anybody.
And she finished high school.
She went to a whole school there.
Then she went to Incarnate Work College.
And then during her senior year, when she lacked, oh I'd say about a semester and maybe a summer.
She decided she wanted to get married.
We tried to talk sense into her, but no, she wouldn't have it any other way.
My son-in-law, whom I'm very happy that she married, was in the Army.
In fact, he still is in the Army.
Is he from here?
No, he is from Canada, but his family came to Florida.
Then Bob became an American citizen and as soon as he was out of college, he was drafted.
And he went into the Army and he met Maria Angela in San Antonio.
He was in Kellyfield, I think.
Yeah, Kellyfield is Army.
And that's where he met her and that's where they met and then he was transferred to the state of Washington.
And that's when they decided they wanted to get married.
So my husband said, well, go to San Antonio and see if you can convince her.
I said, no, I can't.
Couldn't do it.
So we came home and she got married in a big hurry and left for Washington and then came back.
And then Bob was sent to Vietnam.
And those were very trying days for her.
I know they were.
And her baby was born while he was in Vietnam.
Mary Catherine was born while my husband was in Korea.
Is that right?
Mm-hmm.
The war was not going on at the time, but 13 months separation is very bad.
Very bad.
Anyway.
And so that was it.
And then he came... Oh, he was...
He's two years old.
Mm-hmm.
So he...
decided that he was going to do something else.
And he found a position, or John, if you want to call it, with IBM in Houston.
Well, my second son lived and still lives in Houston, and he'll always be there.
He's a psychiatrist.
Oh, really?
He is.
She thought that the fact that her brother was there would make it easier for her.
In fact, they found an apartment in the same complex where he was living.
But naturally, he was going out all the time.
And they had absolutely no social life.
She didn't know who lived next door.
Houston is a tremendously big city.
It's very big.
Much too big for me.
It's much too big for most people.
So we went to spend Thanksgiving with them and Renata, my husband, came home and said, now I'm really, really broken hearted to see the way our daughter lives.
Her home is very well kept and a very nice apartment.
Everything was perfect.
But she had nothing to do except wait for Bob to come home in the evening, eat, and go to bed.
And that was it.
Monday through Friday.
No hail, which she was used to.
So anyway, they decided they were going back into the Army.
And she wrote to him.
No, she called long distance.
They were having a party.
And a friend of mine, Hazel Skinner, answered the phone and says, Miss Skinner, what are you doing at Mother's?
Oh, we're having a good time.
Your mother's having a cocktail party.
We're all having a good time.
So they visited for a little while, and then Jesus says, Angela, it's for you.
It's Maria.
So I went and answered the phone.
I said, well, hello, honey.
So glad you're calling.
Anything wrong?
No, mother, nothing.
There's nothing wrong.
So next morning, the phone rings, and it was Jesus.
Angela, call Maria.
The reason she called you last night was because God has joined the army again.
And she wanted to tell you, but she knew that
You would be upset by it, so she didn't want to tell you that.

So, because I had already told them that it was so ridiculous for them to go get right back into the lion's mouth and this and the other, and they would always live like gypsies with not having a home.
I tried to make it as dark as I possibly could.
But she says, Mother, you taught me that whatever made Daddy happy would make you happy.
So he was sent to El Paso, which was fine.
We visited with him.
And then from El Paso, he was sent to Tokyo.
And she's with him in Tokyo?
No, no, no.
She's here now.
They lived in Tokyo for three years.
Her baby was born, her second child was born in Tokyo.
And we visited them.
Well, there was an alliance convention, national convention, and it was in the Orient, so we went.
Of course, my main attraction was going to Tokyo to see her, and she was very, very upset about leaving us again, and she wrote very interesting letters from Tokyo.
In fact, I say them all, and I told her, someday you might be able to do something, because she has a tremendous...
I guess it's something inborn with her, in her riding.
Well, these experiences and the travel perhaps will be good, because this will develop her ability to ride.
Yes, I'm sure.
But anyway...
After the three years in Tokyo, they sent them to San Antonio, which was wonderful.
Oh, yeah.
In San Antonio, they were going to be there six months.
And then from there, Bob went back to Vietnam.
So when he went to Vietnam, he came back to Laredo.
And they live in a house that belongs to us.
Could I offer you some fruit juice or something?
Oh, that would be very nice.
Would you care for some?
Mr. Bonnie Leyendecker, who was a very close friend of my grandfather.
And so Daddy was trying to find something.
So he went to Mr. Leyendecker and said, I don't have nothing to offer.
Absolutely nothing to offer.
The only thing that I could tell you would be that you could kind of watch over my cotton pickers.
And Daddy said, all right, I'll do it.
And when he'd come home, my grandmother was just crying.
To see her own son, I mean her child, have to do that kind of a work just to survive.
Because actually that's what he was trying to do, keep us from going hungry.
So they would do anything.
And I believe that if they would
If they would have told him, the only thing there is for you to do is pick cotton, he would say, all right, I'll do it.
Maybe he wouldn't have picked, but... Well, there were, in fact, I guess two, well, one very wealthy family that I've talked to in El Paso was never able to recover, really.
And then some who were poorer in Mexico have done quite well.
So there's been a lot of variation.

But just the fact that people have represented every faction of the revolution, the winners and the losers, I think this... Well, there was one thing that, in my opinion, was a great salvation to our family.
And that was the fact that, as I told you, both societies, the Nuevo Laredo and Laredo,
lived as one.
Daddy would come to the, well the people from this side would go to the casino and all that.
And Daddy was everybody's friend.
And by the same token he would come to dances on this side with the best of people.
So you already had contact.
Oh yes, everybody knew him.
And so we didn't have anything
But we still were who we were.
And this can make quite a difference.
Well, this is so important, I think, in Mexico, much more so than it is in the United States.
Your name, who you were.
It didn't really matter what you had.
It was who you were, you know.
This is true in some parts of the United States, too.
New Orleans is a classic example.
And a lot of the little towns.
My mother's family founded a little town in southeast Missouri.
And there's very definitely this who you are.
But it's not thought of in connection with the United States.
But you know, in my case, it didn't bother me to know that my friends, who are the best girls here, had better clothes than I did.
Well, we couldn't afford them, and that was all there was to it.
But nobody dressed to the point where you felt
very much inferior.
In other words, there was not that crazy spending that has taken us over.
Well, if you're sure enough of your status, there's no need for this kind of display.
Because I remember a very, very dear friend of mine, Alice, she used to sometimes come home and she would cry and say, you know what, I don't think Daddy loves me at all.
They gave me sisters.
There were three girls.
Virginia, Esther, and Alice.
And the middle one was sister.
They always would stick on her sister.
There are two things that I want to ask you about that I've been trying.
I hope I can answer.
Oh, I'm sure you can.
The first one relates to your teaching.
And I guess it's a little off the subject, but I know growing up myself,
society where I was supposed to get married and stay home and keep house.
And this was just the only, I was to go to college, but that was to be an educated mother.
And I know that my parents and my husband's parents were both somewhat disapproving of me being what I became.
Now, did you have any, with your career, did you face any of this?
You mean the fact that you were getting married and yet having to keep on?
Well, that you were working, that you had a career, even though you were married and had children.
Did you have any?
Did people ever accuse you of being improper?
Yes, I'll tell you.
I'll never forget one time.
that a friend of mine, I had a party for somebody, and this very, very dear friend of mine who was also a teacher, Cecilia, and this other friend says, oh, some of my friends call me Angelita.
Angelita's house is so pretty, her home is so pretty, but you know, it's a shame because of course she doesn't enjoy having to teach.
And so my friend jumped at her and says, well, you'd be surprised how much she enjoys it.
And one thing I can tell you, her children are not neglected in any way because of the fact that she teaches.
But I've always said this.
You know, when I got married and started teaching, they said, poor Angela.
She has to keep on working.
And now, girls get married.
And they say, isn't it wonderful?
She's going to keep on teaching.
Yes, it's changed a lot.
Even since, I think, even in 10 or 12 years.
They used to feel sorry for us, and now we think, isn't it wonderful?
She still can teach.
You know, another thing that makes it different here is the fact that we have helped so readily with everything.
That would make it different.
It makes it very different because you're able to leave your house.
Yeah, I had a maid.
who raised my children, we kept her for seventeen years.
And if you had something else, you always had two.
I always had two.
One was absolutely dedicated to the children.
Walked them to school.
You remember that Cata used to walk you to Miss Ellis?
She and Blackie and Mariangela.
And she'd go pick her up because our hours didn't coincide.
But you weren't really here under strong social pressures, not because it was an improper thing to do.
This is interesting, because actually I experienced some of that earlier.
What was the other question?
The other question was, how did you happen to meet your husband?
As we say in Spanish, lo conoc en un baile.
Well, she knows what that means.
Yeah, but you did.
And yes, and actually I did.
But of course, mother took us to the dance.
Uh-huh.
And your daddy came, and then who would I dance with?
Yes, yes.
Because mother was keeping an eye on me.
And I think your daddy was chewing gum.
Was he really?
And my mother disapproved terribly.
She says, who was that?
gum chore that I was dancing with.
Really?
And, well, we started going.
Daddy never knew.
Oh, I couldn't have, nobody could come to my house and, I mean, nobody could ask me for a date.
Because...
When you were telling me about your schooling, I thought he was probably rather strict.
Very, very much so.
In fact, I think, not I think, I know he overdid it.
But that was the way he believed, and I don't know, that we had to accept it.
How did you manage then to?
Well, we kept on going together for several years, and then when Mother died, I couldn't see him because we were in mourning, and I didn't want to go anyplace.
And so a man of ours who came to spend some weeks, some days with us,
I told her, I said, Tia Lolita, Renato wants to come and see me, and I don't know what to do.
She said, well, you two and your father, well, he wants to talk to Daddy.
So I told Daddy, I said, Daddy, he already knew.
Renato wants to talk to you.
He says, I have nothing to talk to him about.
I said, well, Daddy, he wants to talk to you because he wants to ask permission to come and see me here.
He says, well, no, I don't want to talk to him.
I said, all right, then I have to.
I'd have to see him on the corner.
That was the first time that I ever said anything that I knew would kind of be disrespectful.
And so that evening he came home, and he didn't tell me.
He told Tia Lolita to tell me, to tell Renato that it was all right.
He could come see me twice a week.
So you became novios.
Yeah, yeah.
We already were novios.
But this was official?
Yes.
And then Daddy went to work in Mexico.
Business got bad and he went to the state of Guerrero.
He was a very close friend of the governor of Guerrero at that time.
And I remember so distinctly that I had gone to school in the evening.
to the Escuela Amarilla Central School because I was taking one of those extension courses.
And Renato met me on the way, and he gave me a letter.
He said, I want you to read this.
He had written Daddy asking me for my hand.
And so Daddy wrote me and asked me, I mean, did I love him enough to want to marry him?
And of course, I said, yes.
He came over for the wedding.
And then we went on a short honeymoon to Monterey.
And Daddy was so jealous.
I remember when I was getting dressed, a lady friend of ours says, doesn't she look pretty in her wedding gown?
And Daddy says, I liked her better without it.
Did he really?
What year was it that you married?
We were married in...
What sort of work was your father doing in Guerrero?
I don't know.
He was working with the government.
It was government work.
This would have been right before.
This would have been during, oh my goodness, he was president before Lzaro Crdenas.
It would have been right before Lzaro Crdenas.
I don't know.
My husband could tell you, but I couldn't.
I can't remember his name either.
So anyway, Daddy was going back to Guerrero.
So he sent a wire to the hotel where we were staying.
Was this Guerrero-Tamalipas or Guerrero-Guerrero?
Instead of Guerrero.
Right, okay.
In Chilpancingo.
Oh, mm-hmm.
I've been there.
And so Daddy sent his wire to Renato.
And he was going by train, and this is the way he worded the wire.
going through Monterey, I would like to see my daughter.
My daughter?
In other words, you can stay in the hotel.
He was very, very extremely jealous.
But then afterwards he realized that Renata was a good husband, a good provider, and a
A good man.
And you say your husband is a customs broker?
Yes.
He's a forwarding agent.
Well, let's see.
One more question.
How do you feel about the revolution now, looking at it?
Do you think it has been a good thing for Mexico or bad?
Or what?
Oh, it definitely has been a good thing for Mexico.
I think revolutions, well-meant revolutions, are always for the best.
And even though Don Porfirio Diaz was such a wonderful man and everything else, he did keep the people of Mexico in a tremendous ignorance.
It was very hard.
He didn't do it because he didn't want them to be educated, but it was too much of a, too big a project.
And the difference in classes in those years I imagine must have been tremendous.
Do you feel like this has, as far as classes are concerned, that Mexico has changed?
I think so.
I think so.
Servants used to be, if not mistreated, in some cases, yes, they were.
But they were looked upon as, she's just my servant.
Now you don't dare do it, because if you do, you'll be without one.
Yeah.
And they have the right, in other words, now they can speak.
But it's still so much more evident.
The class system is so much more evident in Mexico than here.
At least I've found it so.
You haven't been in Mexico.
I've been in Mexico enough to see a great, great difference between
the way people act and say the way they would act in another part of the United States, I find it very, very evident.
I really do.
Just look at the other side, all of them.
It's... Well, they live the way they live because they have a means of it.
Yes, but still...
The means doesn't always give you the right to look down.
I don't think you can look down anymore.
Maybe not consciously put.
Not Luisa.
All right, maybe not the Luisa foot.
I still find it.
I mean, I still notice it.
Hello?
Dr. Nolan, this is my husband.
How do you do?
How do you do?
That's so nice to meet you.
This is her daughter, Mary Catherine.
Hello there.
Hi.
How are you doing?
Where are you going?
She's going to Rio.
Good day.
Good night.
Oh, I'm keeping you.
Better get on down the road.
This has been... What do you think of the revolution, Mr. Zapata?
Oh, the revolution has brought tremendous progress for Mexico.
You compare Mexico today with Mexico 40 years ago, there's a tremendous difference.
You see, for instance, the city of Mexico City, you know, when Porfirio Diaz left, the population was 300,000 people.
No, no, but let's say about 500,000.
The population now is about 11 million.
Monterey, the population of Monterey was 70,000.
Now it's close to a million and a half.
The population of Mexico as a whole was 13 million.
Now it's 55 million people.
Well, but that's not due to... Well, it's the province, you know.
That's due to something else.
No, no, no.
It is a tremendous province, not only... All right, well, better medical care.
Economically.
But Senior Doug told a joke last night.
He's very, very quiet, but nevertheless, we're leaving the Cardinals.
We went to a cocktail of the Cardinals, the consulate,
American Council had, and somebody made a joke about so many children, very good Catholics.
He says, well, no, there was the one that they asked him, how many children do you have?
Well, we have seven.
You must be Catholics.
No, we're Baptists.
So what was the answer?
Well, you must be very Catholic.
Passionate baptism.
That's an interesting way of putting it.
Well, I've noticed the changes.
I was first in Mexico in 1955.
I lived in Mexico City for seven weeks.
I met my husband on that student trip to learn Spanish.
Didn't learn much Spanish, but I did get a husband out of it.
Oh, yeah, eventually, two years later.
And we've been going back ever since.
And we've actually, well, we lived in Monterey three months, one summer, and in Urapan three months, two summers ago, and have traveled over fairly long periods of time.
So we've been watching the changes.
That's a very interesting incident about, not incident, but during the time that right after , she had lived in,
It's Uruapan.
Uruapan.
Uruapan.
Uruapan.
Uruapan.
And so there's Uruapan and what is the name of the... Well, Zakan was the little name.
Zakan.
Zakan.
But she says that most of the... About what percentage of the population doesn't speak Spanish?
Oh.
Well, the one where they don't speak Spanish is Angahuan.
And I would say probably about...
Oh, a third to half of them don't speak Spanish.
This is predominantly the women.
But then 30 years ago, hardly anyone spoke Spanish.
And still, Tarasco.
Tarasco.
Tarasco Indians.
Do you know the history of the Tarasco Indians?
Yeah, some.
Vasco de Quiroga.
He was the one that organized the Indians.
He was quite a remarkable man.
He's very highly respected in Michoacan.
But her knowledge of Mexico is very, very interesting.
Your wife got me talking about my dissertation, and that's dangerous.
When I do that, I can't show you.
That fell into the revolutionary hands, you know.
Old Guerrero was the first one?
How did that happen?
Well, it just happened, you know, that the Collector of Customs was very close to Don Francisco Madero, who was the president, was assassinated.
Mm-hmm.
As collector of customs, you know, he organized an uprising in the old town, you know, fell into the hands of the revolutionaries.
And he was the commander-in-chief of that particular group.
So the federalists, you know, what they used to call it,
They were never able to recapture the town, you know.
And so through Guerrero, you know, the rebels, they imported everything, you know, ammunition.
Oh, that's very interesting.
Yes, it was one of their keythis was in the uprising against Huerta.
Mm-hmm.
Well, what abouthad your family already left Guerrero?
Well, we left for a little while, you know, about two years.
We moved from Guerrero to Zapata.
When was that?
When that particular time, you know.
Oh, at that particular time.
So we went back to the old town and we stayed most of the time, you know, spent most of the revolution there.
In Guerrero?
In Guerrero.
Because there were no, no, there were no battles there.
No.
It was a quiet...
But it was already held by the Caranzistas.
The Caranzistas, you know, about two or three years later, they organized an army from Nuevo Laredo.
They tried to recapture the town, you know, but the Federales were defeated.
And later on, you know, the rebels, they captured Nuevo Laredo.
No regular particular time.
It was a small, very small population.
It was probably about 13,000.
Well, you can judge the progress of Mexico, you know, by just looking at the size of the cities.
And a lot of other things.
Don't you believe also that a lot of the people who live in the country, so to speak, I mean in places where, remote places,
were not accounted for?
Oh, you mean before?
I mean in taking census.
Earlier?
Yes.
This is entirely possible.
But there has been...
They don't have any means to know exactly.

You can see the progress too in the villages where people have electricity and they have used it to establish, you know, crafts of course are lovely but they have now small local industries that bring in more return and you can see it in housing and in sanitation and all kinds of other things all through many of the villages.
Highways, you know.
And in this education.
This is the thing that impresses me most, is the knowledge that children and grandchildren of people who not only were peasant farmers, but who were linguistic Indians, are now university graduates.
are well established in the Mexican middle class.
From one little town of a thousand people, there have, in 28 years, that town has produced 88 professionals.
Every one of whom had to leave town for further education at the end of the sixth grade.
Which, you know, there are a lot of towns in Texas that don't have that record, I don't think.
You know, for the time, probably already was published in the
Reader's Digest, a very interesting article about education in Mexico.
Probably you will remember that they mentioned the fact that they were building a school a day in Mexico.
I believe that.
They're doing a lot.
There's still a lot to be done, but they're making quite an effort.
And it's not just the government can't do it all.
The one town has done it even with only six years of school.
The Indian town, that is the ones who are psychologically Indian, they have the schools, but they won't send their children.
So you can't, you know, education for two,
to achieve when it's available, apparently, from the towns I've studied, it has to come from inside you.
It's one thing for the opportunity to be there, but you have to be willing to take it and to desire to take it.
At least this is what I found in these little towns that I was studying.
And they varied in that some towns were not only willing to, but eager to, and succeeded in not
actually accomplishing a great deal.
And others just either rejected the opportunity or ignored it.
Or, well, there were both.
There was just not paying much attention to it.
And there were some pounds like this.
And then there was the one pound that actually rejected opportunity because it came from a larger society that they resumed.
So there's a lot of choice involved with those people in town.
Well, I have one more question for you.
When did you happen to come to Laredo?
Well, I came to Laredo, let us say, about 1922.
Always.
Why?
Well, I came to Nuevo Laredo first, and then I moved to Laredo, Texas.
In those days, you know, there were no immigration requirements.
All you had to do is cross the border.
So it really didn't make much difference.
Now I started myself here in Laredo.
I've been here quite a time.
She's from Nuevo Laredo, too.
Yeah, now she knows.
She was not a refugee, she was exiled.
Well, that's true, really, in this particular case.
They exiled themselves.
They were self-exiled.
Most of the people, the revolution that came to the United States, it was the best kind of people in Mexico.
The wealthy people, the poor people, they didn't have to move.
Some did.
Some did.
Yes.
Mostly just to get away from the turmoil.
Yes.
let's say, exiled people were the best kind of people, you know.
The ones that fled during the early stages, the refugees from the Madero and then the first stages of the Karenciste revolution were definitely this group.
And it was what I found is that the poorer people tended to come later.
And they were reacting to just the years and years and years of warfare.
Or many Villistas, you know, a price was put on the head of a lot of the men who had fought with Villa.
